questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with vinyl chloride exposure?
Which of the following is not an indirect-acting carcinogen?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Direct-Acting Carcinogens

Indirect-Acting Carcinogens

Mode of action

Directly damage DNA, leading to mutations

Require metabolic conversion to become active (ultimate carcinogens)

Carcinogenic potency

Typically weak

More potent

Endogenous enzymes involved

None

Cytochrome P-450 enzymes play a key role

Examples
  • Alkylating agents (Anti-cancer drugs) like nitrosoureas, cyclophosphamide
  • Acylating agents
  • Aromatic hydrocarbons like benzo[a]pyrene
  • Aromatic Amines, Amides, Azo Dyes (Option B)
  • Natural Plant and Microbial Products like Aflatoxin B1, Griseofulvin, and Betel nuts (Options A, D)
  • Insecticides, fungicides

questions.text: Which of the following radiations is the most common cause of skin cancer?
Which of the following statements regarding H. pylori infection and its association with malignancies is correct ?

options.label: A
options.text: Gastric lymphomas associated with H. pylori infection are primarily of B-cell origin.

options.label: B
options.text: H. pylori strains associated with gastric adenocarcinomas contain the cytotoxin-associated B gene.

options.label: C
options.text: VacA, a toxin from H. pylori, causes gastric cell apoptosis, reducing cancer risk.

options.label: D
options.text: MALT lymphomas associated with t(11;18) translocation respond to anti-H.Pylori therapy.

questions.correct_answer: A. Gastric lymphomas associated with H. pylori infection are primarily of B-cell origin.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the Warburg effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Cancer cells primarily rely on oxidative phosphorylation for ATP production.

options.label: B
options.text: It involves a shift from glycolysis to oxidative phosphorylation in cancer cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Cancer cells exhibit increased glucose uptake and preferentially metabolise glucose via glycolysis, even in the presence of oxygen.

options.label: D
options.text: It is characterised by decreased glucose uptake and utilisation by cancer cells.

questions.correct_answer: C. Cancer cells exhibit increased glucose uptake and preferentially metabolise glucose via glycolysis, even in the presence of oxygen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding Lynch syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It is autosomal recessive in inheritance.

options.label: B
options.text: It is also known as hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.

options.label: C
options.text: It is caused by mutations in genes involved in nonhomologous end-joining repair.

options.label: D
options.text: Amsterdam II criteria are used for diagnosis.

questions.correct_answer: D. Amsterdam II criteria are used for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with a defect in homologous DNA repair?
Which of the following cyclin-CDK combinations is incorrectly matched?
questions.explanation:
Cyclin

CDK

Function

Cyclin A

(Option 1)

CDK1, CDK2
  • Activates DNA replication in the S phase
  • The transition from S phase to the G2 phase

Cyclin B

CDK1
  • Promotes assembly of mitotic spindle (G2-to-M)

Cyclin D

(Option 3)

CDK4, CDK6
  • Promotes G1-to-S transition by phosphorylating Rb

Cyclin E

(Option 4)

CDK2
  • Promotes G1-to-S transition by phosphorylating Rb
  • Initiates DNA synthesis

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of RAS mutation and its associated malignancy.
questions.explanation:
Signal Transduction Protein
(GTP-binding proteins)

Malignancies

KRAS

Colon, Lung, Pancreatic tumours

HRAS

Bladder and kidney tumors

NRAS

Melanomas, AML

GNAS

Pituitary adenoma

GNAQ

Uveal melanoma

questions.text: Which gene mutation, known for encoding a growth factor, is associated with the development of astrocytoma?

Growth factor

Proto-oncogene

Tumour-associated

Platelet-derived growth factor-β

PDGFB (Option A)

Astrocytoma

Fibroblast growth factor

HST (Option B)

Osteosarcoma

FGF3 (Option C)

Urinary bladder and Gastric cancers

Transforming growth factor-α

TGFA

Astrocytoma

Hepatocyte growth factor

HGF (Option D)

Hepatocellular carcinomas

questions.text: Which of the following paraneoplastic syndrome is not associated with lung cancer?
questions.explanation:
Cushing syndrome

Small cell carcinoma of the lung, Pancreatic tumours

SIADH

Small cell carcinoma of the lung

Hypercalcemia

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

Myasthenia(Lambert-Eaton) (Option C)

Bronchogenic carcinoma

Acanthosis nigricans (Option B)

Bronchogenic carcinoma

and clubbing of the fingers

phenomenon

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is FNAC helpful in establishing diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Indications

Contraindications /limitations

Thyroid disorders

Follicular disorders of the thyroid (Limitation) (Option A ruled out)

Breast lesions

Infections, septicemia

Lymph node evaluation

Bleeding disorders

Pancreatic malignancy

Hydatid cyst- Risk of anaphylaxis (Option C ruled out)

Most solid organ masses accessible via FNAC

Testicular cancer- Increased risk of spread of cancer (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: What needle size is typically employed for Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) procedures?
Which of the following is a marker for breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Tumor marker

Associated conditions

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

 
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour)
  • Nonseminomatous germ cell tumour of testis
  • ↑ AFP: abdominal wall defects, neural tube defects
  • ↓ AFP: associated with trisomy 21, 18, and 13 

β-HCG (Option D)

 
  • Nonseminomatous testicular germ cell tumours (choriocarcinoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, mixed germ cell tumour, seminoma)
  • Ovarian cancer: choriocarcinoma (gestational trophoblastic disease)

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Lung cancer (especially in non-small cell cancers)
  • Gastric cancer

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
  • Prostate cancer
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Prostatitis

Calcitonin
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (both sporadic and associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2)

Alkaline phosphatase
  • Metastases to bone or liver
  • Paget disease of the bone

Placental alkaline phosphatase
  • Seminoma

Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Ovarian cancer (dysgerminoma)
  • Testicular germ cell tumours (both seminoma and nonseminoma)
  • Lymphomas
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Neuron specific enolase (NSE)
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Small cell lung cancer
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Neuroblastoma

CA 19–9 (Option A)
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
  • Colon cancer
  • Cholangiocarcinoma

CA 15–3 and CA 27–29
  • Breast cancer

CA 125 (Option B)
  • Ovarian carcinoma
  • Other gynecologic malignancies

S-100 protein (S100A) and (S100B)
  • Malignant melanoma

SMRP
  • Mesothelioma

questions.text: Which of the following tumour is of mesenchymal origin?
questions.explanation:
Mesenchymal Tumours

Epithelial Tumours

Origin
  • Connective tissues and derivatives
  • Blood and lymph vessels
  • Hematopoietic stem cells and lymphoid tissue
  • Meninges
  • Mesothelium
  • Smooth muscles and Skeletal muscles
  • Stratified squamous epithelium
  • Melanocytes and basal cells of the skin
  • Glandular epithelium and epithelium of ducts
  • Respiratory, Hepatic, Renal, Transitional, Testicular, Placental epithelium

Examples
  • Leiomyosarcoma
  • Lipoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Fibrosarcoma
  • Meningioma
  • Synovial sarcoma
  • Adenocarcinoma
  • Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Adenoma
  • Papilloma
  • Seminoma
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Transitional cell carcinoma

Markers
  • Vimentin
  • Desmin
  • S100 Protein
  • Fibronectin
  • Myogenin
  • Cytokeratin
  • Epithelial Membrane Antigen (EMA)
  • E-Cadherin
  • P63, P40
  • Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA)

Characteristic

Directly damage DNA, leading to mutations

Typically weak

None

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with vinyl chloride exposure?
Which of the following tumours do not typically exhibit direct seeding of body cavities?
Which of the following types of cancer is least likely to exhibit distant metastasis?

Which of the following statements is/are True? The basement membrane remains intact in dysplasia. Dysplasia is always irreversible. Pleomorphism is observed in metaplasia. Myositis ossificans is an example of dysplasia.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Metaplasia

Dysplasia

Anaplasia

Definition

Differentiated cell

type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type

Disordered growth and loss of architectural orientation of cells

Lack of cellular differentiation and organisation

Nature (Statement 2)

Adaptive response to stress or injury

Preneoplastic

Associated with malignant transformation

Reversibility

Reversible

Reversible in early stages

(irreversible if whole

the epithelium is involved)

Irreversible

Pleomorphism (Statement 3)

Absent

Present in low-grade

Present in high-grade

Nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio

Normal (1:4 to 1:6)

Increased (↑)

Increased (↑↑↑)

Mitotic figures

Absent/minimal at normal places

Typical mitotic figures present at abnormal places

Atypical, bizarre mitotic figures

present at abnormal places

Basement membrane integrity

Intact

Intact

Breached

Example (Statement 4)

Barret’s oesophagus,

myositis ossificans

Cervical dysplasia of

squamous cells

Carcinoma of the cervix, carcinoma oesophagus

questions.text: Which of the following features is not a characteristic of anaplasia?

What is the most likely diagnosis of a patient with a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the right parotid gland region that is well-defined and heterogeneous, with both epithelial and mesenchymal components present in the biopsy?
